00088             /*
00089                 The flag is true when the vector intersects the
00090                 special world object "screen". In this case, the intersection 
00091                 coordinates presented in following data members are coordinates within 
00092                 the region defined as the screen area.
00093 
00094                 @if SM_COREDATA_LANGUAGE_PYTHON
00095                 def intersectsScreen(self):
00096                     """Returns a boolean indicating that the direction vector intersects with the screen.
00097 
00098                     The flag is true when the vector intersects the
00099                     special world object "screen". In this case, the intersection 
00100                     coordinates presented in following data members are coordinates within 
00101                     the region defined as the screen area.
00102                      """
00103                 @endif
00104              */
00105             virtual bool intersectsScreen() const COREDATA_PURE_METHOD;
00106     
00108             /*
00109                 The field contains the 3D point in world coordinates in meters at which the 
00110                 vector intersects the screen plane defined by the special
00111                 screen object in the world model. The values are valid even when the
00112                 vector does not intersect the screen. In this case the 3D point will be
00113                 outside the region defined as the screen. If the head tracking 
00114                 fails the values are 0.
00115 
00116                 @if SM_COREDATA_LANGUAGE_PYTHON
00117                 def screenIntersectionWorldCoordinates(self):
00118                     """Returns the point as a 3-tuple of floats in world coordinates 
00119                     where the vector intersects the screen plane (in meters).
00120 
00121                     The field contains the 3D point in world coordinates in meters at which the 
00122                     vector intersects the screen plane defined by the special
00123                     screen object in the world model. The values are valid even when the
00124                     vector does not intersect the screen. In this case the 3D point will be
00125                     outside the region defined as the screen. If the head tracking 
00126                     fails the values are 0.
00127                     """
00128                 @endif
00129              */
00130             virtual const fStdVector3& screenIntersectionWorldCoordinates() const COREDATA_PURE_METHOD;
00131     
00133             /*
00134                 The field contains the 2D point in screen coordinates in meters at which the 
00135                 vector intersects the screen plane defined by the special
00136                 screen object in the world model. The values are valid even when the
00137                 cyclops vector does not intersect the screen. In this case the 2D point will be
00138                 outside the region defined as the screen. If the head tracking 
00139                 fails the values are 0.
00140 
00141                 @if SM_COREDATA_LANGUAGE_PYTHON
00142                 def screenIntersectionScreenCoordinates(self):
00143                     """Returns the point as a 2-tuple of floats in screen coordinates

00151                     fails the values are 0.
00152                    """
00153                 @endif
00154              */
00155             virtual const fStdVector2& screenIntersectionScreenCoordinates() const COREDATA_PURE_METHOD;
00156     
00158             /*
00159                 The field contains the 2D point in pixels at which the 
00160                 vector intersects the screen plane defined by the special
00161                 screen object in the world model. The values are valid even when the

00163                 will be outside the region defined as the screen. If the head
00164                 tracking fails the values are 0.
00165 
00166                 @if SM_COREDATA_LANGUAGE_PYTHON
00167                 def screenIntersectionPixelCoordinates(self):
00168                     """Returns the point as a 2-tuple of ints in pixel coordinates

00170

00178                 @endif
00179              */
